sense.name: a period of, at least two consecutive quarters, negative economic growth
sense.examples: The last recession lasted more than two years. New England saw a loss of jobs during the recession. The boom was followed by a recession followed by another boom.

sense.name: a small, physical concavity
sense.examples: The scar formed an inch-long recession on his cheek. The freezing and thawing has caused recessions in the ground.

sense.name: a ceremonial march of withdrawing, opposite of a procession
sense.examples: We arrived at the cathedral just in time to see the recession of the clergy and choir. The organist played a different melody during the recession of the graduating class.

sense.name: the act of relinquishing something, ceding back
sense.examples: The treaty forced the country's recession of the border territory back to the neighboring state. The judge ordered the recession of publishing rights back to the author.

sense.name: act of becoming distant, moving away from
sense.examples: Mars is in recession currently. The recession of other galaxies from ours is indicated by their red shift. Poor dental hygiene may lead to recession of the gums. (move farther from teeth)
